38.48.text:
Our aerial journey begins at Cape Town and
Table Mountain before heading south, round

43.52.text:
the Cape of Good Hope, and then back up past
some of the best known vineyards to Stellenbosch.

49.84.text:
We then head east to Hermanus and whale watching
before flying along the Garden Route to Port

55.57.text:
Elizabeth in the Eastern Cape and on up the
Wild Coast to Durban in KwaZulu-Natal before

62.33.text: heading inland to the Drakensberg Mountains.

68.89.text:
And where better to begin our aerial journey
than Cape Town and on top of one of the most

73.57.text:
recognisable mountains in the world -- Table
Mountain.

84.86.text: The mountain towers over the city.

86.58.text:
It is two miles long and 3,500ft above sea
level.

93.14.text:
It was named Table Mountain by Antonio de
Saldhana, the first European to sail into

99.95.text:
The 
flat top is flanked on one side by Devil's

108.34.text: peak and the other Lion's Head.

114.01.text:
One of the most famous views of the mountain
is from the sea to the north where it is possible

118.42.text: to see how much it dominates the city.

123.70.text:
More often than not the mountain top is covered
by a white 'table cloth' when clouds are formed

129.10.text:
by a warm south easterly wind rising up the
mountainside and meeting colder air at the

135.53.text: And the views from the top are spectacular.

142.84.text:
But for those who prefer the easy way up a
cable car takes you to the plateau.

152.86.text:
And standing in the mountain's shadow is a
memorial to a man who more than any other

157.29.text:
played such an important, as well as controversial,
role in the story of South Africa -- Cecil

165.65.text:
At the end of the 19th century he used his
wealth to build a British Empire in the new

170.28.text:
world through mining concessions and creating
British protectorates.

175.65.text:
He created Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe, and dreamt
of a 'red' line of British power from Cape

187.60.text:
Cape Town is a true cosmopolitan city and
a major tourist destination.

194.18.text:
Its development over the centuries has been
influenced by Dutch, British and Cape Malay

202.71.text:
Today modern buildings stand next to historic
ones including the grand City Hall built in

208.51.text:
1905 and the much earlier Castle of Good Hope
built around 1670

215.76.text:
One of the most dominant features of the city
is the new football stadium at Green Point

222.41.text:
It holds 68,000 people and was built for the
2010 world Cup.

227.51.text:
Close by the stadium is the old Victoria and
Alfred Waterfront, which was gradually redeveloped

235.22.text:
in the late 1980's into residential and shopping
areas along with restaurants and expensive

241.36.text:
hotels, including an island with forty suites
surrounded by other luxury apartments.

251.02.text:
But, there is another Island just off the
Cape Town coast, which stands in marked contrast

261.72.text:
This is Robben Island, which lies five miles
north of Cape Town.

265.83.text:
It was a prison and had been since the end
of the 17th century.

270.76.text:
And it was here in 1963 that Nelson Mandela
was incarcerated for eighteen of his twenty

280.67.text:
All prisoners had to do back breaking hard
labour in the lime quarry close by the prison,

286.81.text: and existed on very basic rations.

290.95.text:
Today the prison is a museum and the whole
island a World heritage Site.

297.49.text:
Perhaps the last word about this place should
come from Nelson Mandela himself when he reflected

302.25.text: back on his time spent here.

304.80.text:
'It is true that Robben Island was once a
place of darkness, but out of that darkness

311.77.text:
has come a wonderful brightness, a light so
powerful that it could not be hidden behind

323.44.text:
Another contrast is between the affluent centre
of Cape Town and the townships on the city

331.52.text:
This is Khayelitsha, home to two million people
and built during the Apartheid era for the

341.06.text:
Under the new government brick buildings are
being put up to improve the housing, but the

345.87.text: corrugated tin shanty towns still exist.

349.62.text:
It is a very different story on the west side
of the city where modern apartment blocks

358.14.text:
line the shore at Sea Point and up the sides
of Lion's head.

364.76.text:
One of the glories of South Africa is its
coastline, which stretches for nearly eighteen

369.37.text:
hundred miles and boasts some of the most
beautiful beaches in the world.

375.42.text: And Noordhoek Beach is one of them.

377.51.text:
A four mile stretch of white sand and deep
blue sea.

381.51.text:
But this beauty can be deceptive, because
very quickly a storm can turn the sea into

386.72.text:
a fearsome maelstrom, which over the centuries
has driven many a ship onto the shore.

394.80.text:
All around the coast rusting wrecks can be
seen -- proof, if proof was needed, of how

404.04.text:
And especially around the Cape of Good Hope
where gale-force winds and tidal races can

409.97.text: drive unsuspecting ships onto the rocks.

416.64.text:
Cape Point lighthouse replaced an earlier
one built higher up on the cape, because in

421.57.text:
1911, as a result of the old one being shrouded
in fog and the light obscured a Portuguese

428.34.text:
liner -- the Lusitania was driven onto the
rocks.

433.21.text:
There was no lighthouse in 1488 when the European
explorer Bartolomeu Dias discovered the Cape

445.97.text:
He erected a cross, which was later replaced
with this replica, as a memorial to his discovery,

451.94.text:
and is interestingly used by sailors today,
as a navigation point.

460.22.text:
The weather patterns around the Cape area
do have one very beneficial effect -- and

467.50.text:
Because South Africa is one of the worlds
great wine producers with a history that goes

472.45.text:
back to the Dutch settlers in the late 17th
century.

477.12.text:
These are just some of the beautifully maintained
historic estate houses in the shadow of Table

487.64.text:
The main area of the Cape Wine industry is
to the east of Cape Town around Stellenbosch.

494.17.text:
One of the earliest estates is Boschendal,
which has a history stretching back to 1685.

503.61.text:
The old Manor house has been enlarged and
altered over the years and what we see today

514.71.text:
Time to head for the coast and a place which
has become most associated with whale watching

522.69.text:
Back in the 19th century when whales were
spotted the boats would put to sea and the

529.05.text:
Today when whales are spotted it is cameras
that shoot the whales.

534.77.text:
From the shore it is possible to see Right
Whales from June through to December, as they

540.03.text: arrive to calve in the shelter of the bay.

543.27.text:
These huge barnacled creatures, often with
calves, can be seen close to the shore quietly

552.68.text:
Though out at sea they can be seen breaching,
an action that is still not truly understood.

567.92.text:
Whatever the answer it is a truly dramatic
sight.

577.95.text:
One of the best known stretches of coast straddles
the Western Cape and the Eastern Cape and

582.66.text: is known as the Garden Route.

584.68.text: It runs from Mossel Bay to Storms River.

590.07.text:
In 1780 a visiting naturalist noted that 'Nature
has made an enchanted abode of this beautiful

602.80.text:
There are many outstanding features to attract
visitors including a dramatic coastline.

609.90.text:
Swim from the wide beach at Nature's Valley,
part of the Tsitsikamma National Park.

616.21.text:
Visit a seal colony on Robberg Peninsular,
and watch the hundreds of Cape Fur Seals.

621.32.text:
In the winter the seal pups are born, and
you can see them play under the watchful eyes

629.91.text:
Hike along the Otter Trail and truly get back
to nature, as numbers are limited and there

634.88.text: are only a few facilities along the way.

639.09.text:
It takes five days and is one of the most
popular trails in the country.

642.97.text: It is a tough but rewarding experience.

647.60.text:
If a more peaceful pursuit is wanted then
there are a number of golf courses along the

655.88.text:
This one is Pinnacle Point Golf resort, where
on some of the holes you really don't want

667.68.text:
The road bridge across the River Bloukrans
is the highest single span bridge in the world

674.56.text:
and the perfect place to hurl yourself off
-- attached to a bungee rope of course.

682.53.text:
The drop holds various entries in the Guinness
Book of Records

695.81.text:
The Garden Route is also a very popular place
to live and towns like Plettenberg have grown

701.27.text: up into large and successful resorts.

705.00.text:
And for those with the means there are some
outstanding modern cliff top houses complete

710.29.text: with amazing views along the coast.

715.56.text:
At Noetzie Beach, which has been used as a
holiday site for generations, there are a

720.40.text: series of modern castles dating from the 1930's.

725.35.text:
Using local stone the houses began to look
like castles and it only took a few turrets

730.24.text:
and a bit of castellation to complete the
picture.

735.34.text:
Today the five castles are a mixture of private
homes and luxury hotels.

744.15.text:
To the east of the Garden Route is Algoa Bay
and the country's third largest port and fifth

752.05.text:
In the centre of the city is the Donkin Reserve,
which is surrounded by many historic buildings

759.76.text:
including the Campanile Tower built in 1923
to commemorate the British settlers arriving

768.55.text:
But there is an older building - Fort Frederick,
built by the British in 1799 to prevent a

779.79.text:
And one of the newest is the Nelson Mandela
Bay Stadium.

785.00.text:
With a capacity of just under 50,000, the
stadium hosts both Rugby and football matches

793.66.text:
An important milestone was its role as one
of the World Cup venues.

801.69.text:
On the north side of the bay is the Alexandria
Dune Field, one of the largest active dune

808.69.text:
The wind has created patterns in the sand
that are always shifting and changing.

815.34.text:
The dunes are flanked by a strip of indigenous
forest.

823.21.text:
Wildlife is one of South Africa's greatest
assets and close to Port Elizabeth is the

828.01.text:
Shamwari Game reserve - the largest private
reserve in the country and one of the top

836.88.text:
Several lodges are dotted around the 60,000
acre site and the reserve offers visitors

842.05.text:
a glimpse of the big five -- Elephants, Rhinos,
Buffalos, Lions and Leopards.

849.64.text:
Most are shy creatures and the presence of
our helicopter means they hide from view.

857.16.text:
However, these Zebra and Wildebeest do not
seem too worried.

872.39.text:
The next stretch of coastline is perhaps the
most dramatic and the most beautiful -- the

882.82.text:
This is an area of outstanding beauty and
one of the country's most underdeveloped areas,

888.18.text:
where communities still pursue age old traditions
and much of the land is owned by the local

897.62.text:
One such tradition is taking the cattle to
the beach.

902.03.text:
There's no grass or drinking water, but rather
like humans they just seem to want to relax,

910.51.text: sleep and generally chew the cud.

914.74.text:
All along the Wild coast this sight can be
seen.

920.63.text:
Perhaps the most iconic place along the coast
is the Hole in the Wall.

926.45.text:
This huge detached cliff was separated from
the land thousands of years ago and softer

931.75.text:
rock in the centre has eroded away leaving
a hole.

937.43.text:
The local people call it 'The Place of Thunder'
because when the sea crashes through the hole

942.74.text:
the sound is like thunder and can be heard
some distance away.

952.41.text:
The erosion has created a sheltered and safe
place to swim, and is one of the most popular

957.62.text: places to visit on the Wild Coast.

965.50.text:
And on a hill above the bay a group of Xhosa
women wash clothes in a way that has not altered

973.25.text:
Fresh water, a convenient bush and a warm
wind is all that's needed for a perfect day's

978.50.text:
washing unless a helicopter comes along to
disturb it.

990.69.text:
Inland from the coast groups of round houses
known as Rondavels can be seen in clusters,

996.29.text:
surrounded by vegetable patches and enclosures
for cattle.

1001.12.text:
They are built in the traditional manner using
thatch with earth and cow dung walls.

1011.06.text:
These round houses can be seen all the way
up the east coast and in places the thatch

1015.36.text:
has been replaced by corrugated tin, and the
earth and cow dung walls with cement blocks

1020.88.text:
or bricks, but the shape has remained the
same.

1025.88.text:
Originally built with no services, many now
have electricity and running water, with a

1040.01.text:
Rivers provide much needed water as well as
a offering locals the opportunity to swim

1044.98.text:
and get cool, but this peaceful looking river
soon gives way to a 500ft drop into a dark

1059.70.text:
These are the Magwa Falls, which were created
as a result of seismic activity when the ground

1065.56.text:
split open thousands of years ago to create
this impressive gorge.

1072.65.text:
At the end are the falls, and they can be
seen from several vantage points.

1081.52.text: It's an impressive and majestic sight.

1091.78.text:
Equally impressive are these rare waterfalls,
which drop directly into the sea.

1100.76.text:
There are not that many of them in the world
and on the Wild Coast you can find two

1109.35.text:
This one is Waterfall Bluff, and here the
water cascades down a near 200ft drop.

1120.23.text:
The falls attract visitors all year round,
even though it's in a very remote part of

1129.68.text:
And another reason for visiting this part
of the coast is to see the wonderful rock

1138.61.text:
It's free standing, and over the centuries
has been sculpted by the sea and wind, and

1143.90.text:
it does indeed take on the appearance of a
great flying buttress on a medieval cathedral.

1153.84.text:
Over the border in KwaZulu Natal sugar cane
production provides much needed employment

1161.00.text:
And most of the country's sugar comes from
this part of the country

1168.60.text:
There are well over 30,000 registered growers,
and parts of the landscape are covered with

1176.75.text:
When the cane is cut it goes to one of the
mills.

1182.05.text:
And this one is on the coast at Bazley Beach
close to Durban.

1190.01.text:
The delicious burnt sugar smell spreads downwind
for several miles.

1198.12.text:
Our route now takes us up the coast to South
Africa's third largest city, and busiest port

1207.99.text:
The harbour is natural -- one of only a few
on this stretch of coast and was opened in

1213.33.text:
the 1840's when it was known as the Port of
Natal

1218.77.text:
But perhaps Durban is most famous for its
sea front and beaches and is in complete contrast

1226.31.text: to the Wild Coast we have just seen.

1233.50.text:
Here are all the usual ingredients of a different
style of tourism - theme parks, large hotels

1247.63.text:
Durban also played its part in the World Cup
story at the Moses Mabhida Stadium, which

1253.87.text:
comes complete with a funicular cab that takes
visitors to the top of the arch for breathtaking

1259.19.text: views over the city and coast.

1265.91.text:
Inland from Durban is the Valley of a Thousand
Hills, which is very much part of the Zulu

1270.66.text:
kingdom founded at the beginning of the 19th
century by Shaka Zulu who united tribes together

1281.90.text:
At the height of his empire Shaka commanded
an army of over 50,000 Zulu warriors.

1291.35.text:
Today the area is full of small villages and
farms, which dot this beautiful landscape,

1296.30.text: and have changed very little over the centuries.

1304.60.text:
And for centuries the Umgeni River has flowed
over the Howick Falls.

1311.58.text:
The Zulu people call the falls KwaNogqaza,
meaning 'Place of the Tall One'.

1322.80.text:
European settlers first saw the falls in the
early 1800's, and when the river was in flood,

1329.18.text:
some lost their lives trying to cross the
river upstream and getting swept over the

1342.80.text:
From here it's only a few miles to South Africa's
highest mountain range, which in total runs

1358.10.text:
The Zulu's refer to the mountains as uKhahlamba,
meaning Barrier of Spears - in Africaans its

1369.84.text:
Drakensberge, which translates as Dragon Mountains
- where vultures glide on the rising air.

1381.38.text:
To the north is another spectacular natural
rock formation -- the Amphitheatre

1391.97.text:
This awe-inspiring natural feature is one
of the most impressive cliff faces in the

1397.10.text:
world, and dominates the Royal Natal National
Park.

1405.29.text:
A small stream runs off the top and drops
just over 3,000ft to the valley below.

1416.13.text:
This makes the Tugela Falls the second highest
waterfall in the world - by only a hundred

1422.04.text: feet from the Angel Falls in Venezuela.

1432.68.text:
Perhaps the best known mountain in the Drakensberg
Range is -- Cathedral Peak.

1440.67.text:
And from the hotel in the valley there is
a clear view up to the summit.

1445.46.text:
And by flying up the path to the top the climb
will take us less than a minute.

1452.03.text: So sit back and enjoy the ride.

1478.42.text:
The views from the top of Cathedral Peak are
spectacular and perfect place to end this
